metadata.case_name: Abdul Rajak Murtaja Dafedar v. State

facts.text: Derailment of Poona-Wasco Express train at Vaddi bridge beyond Miraj station at about 4.40 a.m. on October 10, 1966, resulting in five bogies capsized, ten persons died, and large number received grievous injuries.

Appellant removed fish plates, nuts, bolts etc. of rail joint near Vaddi bridge No. 215 on Miraj-Mhaisal track at Km. No. 743/9-10 between 4.05 a.m. and 4.50 a.m. on October 10, 1966, causing derailment and deaths of 10 persons.
Appellant was gangman in gang No. 13 under Mukadam Laxman Madar and Keyman Bapu Sopana, area Km 741/3 to 747/5 including Vaddi bridge.
Appellant quarrelled with Laxman Madar over duties; on October 9, 1966, altercation where appellant rushed at Laxman with pick axe; Laxman reported incident.
Ramchand Sadre, PW 37, Railway Protection Force Sainik, saw appellant going on track at 3 or 3.15 a.m. on October 10, 1966 from G point at Miraj station.
Goods train No. 239 passed Vaddi bridge at 4.05 a.m.; appellant then removed fish plates, keys, jaws of 18th rail on right side with spanner.
Engine driver heard thud-thud, applied brakes; engine derailed, tender tilted, first bogie in stream, second completely in stream, third telescoped, fourth and fifth derailed.
Removed fish plates, nuts, bolts, keys, jaws found scattered undamaged near affected joint; another fish plate and nut on embankment.
Engine driver complained to PSI Bendigiri; panchanama prepared, site cordoned off.
On October 10, 1966 at 7 a.m., gangmen including appellant collected at pole 744/4, detained by police for statements.
On October 10, 1966 night at 8.30 p.m., police dog Sheru smelled affected joint, went to fish plate on embankment, then pounced on appellant from row of persons.
On October 17, 1966, appellant gave memorandum statement to produce spanner hidden between poles 744/6-7; produced spanner dug from earth.
On October 29, 1966, appellant confessed before Executive Magistrate Ex.130.
Appellant convicted by Additional Sessions Judge Sangli in Sessions Case No.9/1967 under ss.302,307,325,427 IPC and S.126 Indian Railways Act; death under 302.
Bombay High Court dismissed Criminal Appeal No.1166/1967 and confirmed death sentence on November 17, 1967.
Appellant denied altercation with Laxman, denied threatening with pick axe, denied confession (did not understand Marathi), denied leading to spanner, denied dog pouncing on him.
Appellant arrested October 10, 1966 at 11 p.m., remand till October 18, then jail from October 25; produced before Magistrate October 28 for preliminary questioning, confessed October 29.

legal_issues.text: Whether the confession Ex.130 recorded by Executive Magistrate was voluntary, given prolonged police custody.
Whether discovery of spanner at instance of appellant is admissible and corroborates guilt.
Whether evidence of dog tracking by Sheru is admissible and reliable to prove guilt.

petitioner_arguments.text: Confession not voluntary due to prolonged police custody for at least a fortnight before recording on October 29, 1966.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Nathu v. State of U.P. AIR 1956 SC 56

petitioner_arguments.text: Wife's visits to police station induced confession.
Lower courts ought not to have relied on dog tracking evidence as inadmissible and unreliable.

respondent_arguments.text: Confession voluntary as appellant in jail custody for four days prior, warned by Magistrate, 24 hours to think.
No inducement by wife; she visited only twice, no suggestion of coercion to police or in statement.
Spanner discovery at appellant's instance corroborates confession; evidence of DSP and panchas reliable.
Prosecution evidence including PW37 sighting, confession, spanner discovery conclusively proves guilt even without dog evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Confession voluntary: appellant in judicial custody four days (Oct 25-28), preliminary questioning Oct 28 with warning, 24 hours to reflect; not parallel to Nathu or Swaran Singh cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prolonged police custody explained by subsequent jail time; no inducement proven.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence of wife's inducement; denied by police, not suggested further, appellant did not complain of coercion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial and High Court correctly found voluntary.

court_reasoning.text: Spanner discovery valid: memorandum Ex.112, led to spot 5 furlongs away, dug out spanner; corroborates confession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence of DSP PW86 and panchas accepted.

court_reasoning.text: Dog tracking evidence, even if inadmissible, not needed as confession and spanner conclusively prove guilt; dogs have thought processes risking error.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not expressing concluded opinion on admissibility but of little weight.

holdings.text: Dog evidence not relied upon; other evidence sufficient for conviction.
Conviction under ss.302,307,325,427 IPC and S.126 Railways Act affirmed; death sentence confirmed.

precedents_cited.relevance: Prolonged custody preceding confession stamps it involuntary unless explained.

precedents_cited.case_name: Swaran Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Facts not parallel to prolonged custody case.
Dog tracking evidence admitted as handler reports instrument-like movements, not hearsay.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction for murder, attempt to murder, voluntarily causing grievous hurt, mischief.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court affirmed Bombay High Court judgment dated November 17, 1967 dismissing appeal and confirming conviction and death sentence by Sessions Court.

key_quotes.text: "prolonged custody immediately preceding the making of the confession was sufficient, unless it was properly explained to stamp it as involuntary."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishing Nathu case on confession voluntariness.

key_quotes.text: evidence of dog tracking, even if admissible, is not ordinarily of much weight.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's view on reliability of dog evidence.

key_quotes.text: the confession of the appellant Ex. 130 and the discovery of the spanner conclusively proves the charges.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for affirming conviction without dog evidence.
